text:
Highly recommend Beatrix!

We came on a Saturday night for one of my best friends birthday dinner celebration. I strongly recommend making a reservation! To get seated, make sure your party is there. You can make reservations through OpenTable and collect those points!

During the pandemic, they closed ‚Äúw Fulton market‚Äù street and all of the restaurants have outdoor seating and pods available. I thought this was a great idea and it‚Äôs going to be so nice for warmer weather nights in the Chi. We did sit inside. All staff did have on mask and hand sanitizer is available. Guests are required to wear masks while in the restaurant, masks are required during all interactions with the service team and only to be removed when eating or drinking. Before seating, all guest did have our temperature checked. They have digital menus and it does say On their menu, to help offset restrictions on their business resulting from the pandemic, there is a a 5% surcharge added to the check. Similar to other restaurants you can let them know if you want it removed.

The ambiance is chic, dimmed lighting and the space is well-decorated. I loved the light fixtures, I‚Äôm weird! The tables were spaced apart, so we didn‚Äôt feel as if we were on top of anyone which was nice. The chairs for the round table were ether cushioned or non, all very comfortable.

They had a great selection of beverages and wine list. My friends and I all participated in the restaurant week menu. This is $39 per person and the dinner menu is available daily after 4:00PM. You get to select one of their starters, entrees and dessert, as well as one their cocktails listed. This was such a great deal and I highly recommend to take advantage of it! The portions were perfect for one person or even if you wanted to share so the other guest can order something different too.

In our party, for the starters we tried their hummus which came with a delicious fresh tomatoes and cucumber salad, flavorful hummus and warm naan. I was hesitant about combining the cold tomatoes on top of the hummus/naan, but it was so delicious! We also tried their local burrata with roasted beets and crispy quinoa. I am personally not a beets person, but two of our friends in our party enjoyed it. The only con was, they wanted more of the bread.

For entrees, one of our friends tried their Cavatelli with chicken bolognese and the remaining of our party ordered the skirt steak chimichurri. Both dishes were cooked perfectly and had flavor, they were delicious! The skirt steaks came with fries and grilled shishito peppers. The peppers were a good combo with the steak as they were bit smoky, but they didn‚Äôt have spice to them. I do enjoy spice, so I would have liked that, but even so still a delicious combination. The entrees were a good size portion, good to eat alone or again to share (COVID friendly of course).

For dessert, we tried their oh my! Carmel pie, and the pie definitely fits the name. Oh my, oh my, it was fantastic. I am normally not a caramel person and when I first saw the pie I was like oh great look how thick this is I‚Äôm not going to eat it and it is complete opposite! It was so smooth and creamy! And the shortbread cookie crust was my favorite part. We also tried their chocolate cake which was very heavy, but delicious! I highly recommend either dessert, and the side of whip cream I would say it is, but obviously made better was very much appreciated!

Our server was fantastic, sadly I didn‚Äôt get his name and I don‚Äôt have my Receipt. He was very friendly and made sure we were good all night. Since my friend did not want a  candle for her birthday or to sing, he did give my friend a to-go dessert which was very sweet and made her feel special.

business_name: The Centre for Oral Surgery in Joliet
text:
This was an absolutely amazing experience!  My oldest son needed 4 impacted molars removed, and I was not pleased with the reviews of the places recommended by his dentist and orthodontist and found this place myself.

They were incredibly thorough in making sure they had all the paperwork, x-rays and other models before the event.  We were given a care package prior to the surgery (something we purchased) to assist in reducing the swelling and to clean the wounds.

We had a meeting prior to the surgery which covered everything that was going to happen with a clear outline of the process, paper work, and billing.

The day itself was so smooth it was amazing.  We arrived a little before the scheduled time, my son was seen around 20 minutes later, and the surgery itself was estimated to be 45 minutes and it was.  We were in an out much quicker than I had expected.  In addition to that, I was able to get all necessary meds at a vending machine (InstyMeds) after the surgery very easily.

My son had a headwrap for the ice packs, we were given extra gauze, chapstick for the  chapped lips that occur during the procedure, extra ice packs, documentation to go home, and even a blanket to take with us!  Anesthesia can give you the shivers so that was an amazing touch.  We received meds for the pain, anti biotics, and meds to help the swelling, which should make this process as pleasant as one can hope to expect.

Our appointment was at 8:40 and I believe we were home before 11!  Very efficient in every detail!  I am totally glad we went with this centre.
Totally awesome in every way!

text:
We go here about once a year.  Always for a "special occasion".   This time was no different.  We went to celebrate our friend David leaving us.  We arrived to a ZOO, at best.  We had reservations for 6:30.  We were given a beeper, and told to WAIT.  Yea, stand up and WAIT with the other 50 people.  No place to sit.  AND, not bar service.  Just stand and WAIT.  A bit of a stupid business decision, as they could have sold us 3 drinks.

EVENTUALLY we were called.  6:50 for our 6:30 reservation.  We were seated with a nice couple, and 4 ladies.  The couple was out on a "date".  Dressed to the nines, and holding hands.  The ladies looked like they had come from a soccer game, as they were dressed in dirty jeans and t-shirts.  A bit strange, but each to their own.

Our server was NOT into his job, tonight.  NO show.  No production.  Just cut to the chase and make the food.  He seemed quite over-worked.  He was a bit flustered by all the "special" requests.  Things like no shrimp, no noodles, give mine to him/her, etc.  He messed up the couple's order three times.   He was flirting with the girls - although they did keep referring to my son, my husband.  He divided food a bit heavy towards the girls, but hard to tell as they were the PICKIEST eaters I have seen.  Not a one of them could eat the meal as provided.  They alll had to omit or swap some food item.   This is NOT the place for custom cooked food.
One of the ladies then went BALISTIC!!!!   Laid into the guy.  Yelled, screamed, all with the back-up choir of her friends.
The gentleman tried to explain his position.  He then appologized.  She would not accept his apology and kept on screaming.

As we left, the building we were accosted in the parking lot by one of the ladies husbands.  He physically threw our friend to the ground.   The manger did come out.  He managed to get the guy to leave.  The wife was crying.  The manager again, said he was sorry.  NOW he knew he had incorrectly identified WHO was the problem.

By now many reading this want to know why I fault the restaurant, and why the bad review for OTHER PEOPLE's behavior.   SOOOOO......

Shogun OVER-BOOKED that night.  It was ONLY 6:30 and they were 20 mins behind.   They put too many people at the table.  They did not have adeuate staff, or resources for the number of people.  They got GREEDY.

They also were taking ANYONE.   The women were NOT dressed appropriately for this restaurant.   The simply did not belong.  They were not there for the show and fancy experience this restaurant offers.  It is the ONLY reason one would pay $25 - $30 a plate for this food.

The manager removed the WRONG people.  The cook did not do a great job, and then it was improperly addressed. This is Shogun's problem.

In the end the couple will likely never return.
It is 99% probable that the three of us will not return.
Will four ladies go out on the town, husbandless, in the near future.  I doubt that too.
Shogun aleniated five people, and MIGHT get the four to return.  And when they do they will act like jerks again.

Shame as we really liked the Shogun experience better than Nipon's.   So far Nipons has screened their customers, and turned away business, to protect their reputation.
prediction_reason: The review mentions a specific artist who was performing at the bar, indicating a genuine experience related to the location.

text:
The place is very old school, looks like it hasn't been redecorated since opening in 1962. That's ok, but different. What confuses me is the menu. It's got a huge range, from decently priced burgers to highly overpriced entrees. The most confusing was the Pepper Steak at the same $34 price point as a 9oz filet. Yeah.

I had the fish and chips, which was ok. The chips were think cut attempts at kettle chips, not fries, showing a lack of understanding of the dish. It wasn't seasoned to speak of, not even the chips.

They were also out of green beans and ice cream. Just weird.

Overall, it's pretty old school, but in need of better cooking and supply control.
prediction_reason: The review details a positive experience with food and service at the restaurant, and the 5-star rating aligns with the content of the text.

text:
This restaurant is located within the lobby of the Chicago Thompson Hotel.  The upside to this is a lovely, close-by space in which to enjoy a pre- or post-dinner cocktail off of their menu.  The downside is that a trip to the bathroom requires a trek:  down a flight of stairs, behind a strange door off to the right of the host stand.

Everything we ordered from the menu was delicious and perfectly prepared; our server explained how to choose selections from the unusual menu, and had us order everything (except dessert) upfront, so the flow from the kitchen could be paced accordingly.  The market-price Branzino was a splurge, but did not disappoint!  The only thing that could have improved the experience was the attention to detail by some of the servers -- such as setting the table with plates and utensils before, or simultaneously with the presentation of the appetizer and dessert courses.  They did not appear short on servers during the night we went, but it seemed as though some were pulling more than their share of the weight, due to the inexperience of others.  The seating at the tables was a tight squeeze--so much so that it almost felt communal (with no way to not listen in on your neighbors' conversations, or for them to not hear yours!)  I will most likely return, but not until the service issues are ironed-out AND I can confirm I will enjoy my meal from one of the booths, which offer more privacy.

business_name: Museum of Science and Industry, Chicago
text:
This review is written from the perspective of an adult visiting with another adult, and visiting again after several visits over many years.

Given that, the sheer number of children to be navigated around, when you're not visiting with children of your own, was a bit distracting. And although new exhibits have been added, enough is the same over the years that some of the "wow" factor has been dulled over time.

Note that we went specifically for the Mythbusters exhibit, and were greatly disappointed by the small size, the lack of any real substance to the exhibit, and the additional cost that gave little in return.

I think it's still a great place to visit as a first-timer, and definitely with children, but as an adult who's made the trip numerous times before, I think there is little left to offer.

text:
Amazing experience, family friendly, helpful people, price is right, and starved rock right there across the street!! 2017.

Update 2018 Holiday.
We had a bad experience and won't come back, after we booked several weeks prior to Christmas we were told the pool would not be working (weeks after we booked), we were ok with that, they also promised all of the other amenities weather permitting available and additional activities for the kids, well, that didn't happened, movies closed, mini golf dirty with sticks and leaves all over couldn't play without the balls getting stuck inside the pipes we manually removed the leaves, the restaurant had odd hours due to lack of customers, they kept the cafeteria closed the whole stayed which was about 4 days, we were never informed it was going to be this way.
When we checked in I was charged the stay twice, and there was a discrepancy with the charges made to the point that I couldn't do room charged because the ladies were confused, I went to have breakfast came back and they were still trying to figure it out, I had to call my bank to get my money back, after about 3 hours of dealing with this situation, I was given free complementary passes for breakfast buffet a special event for Christmas they were hosting, the menu stated pancakes and other  food items, we went to eat that morning and were told the pancakes were for lunch not breakfast ????.

The suite we stayed at had a broken bed and I had to take a pain pill for my back next morning, the carpet was so black and filthy we couldn't walk with our socks on without them getting black in the bottom with just a few steps And I wish I was exaggerating, the cable TV was only in 1 out of 3 TVs, and for story time the hunter and the bear didn't even moved, the kids were so bored!
We had to drive to the next town to get food because as I stated, the restaurant was closed most part of the day, at night the bar closed due to no customers.
I emailed Jacky D. and she forearms my email to the front desk manager I got a call from her while I was working and couldn't pick up, I called her back and was told she was not available, I do not have her email or any other form of contact, it would have been easier to emailed me.
Anyways, I wish they will inform customers that due to lack of customers (during certain seasons) most amenities will be closed and restaurant will operate based on how many guests the hotel has. We decided to take our business elsewhere next time. Such a shame.

text:
The coffee's good, the staff are polite and the place itself is nice, but one thing I'm not crazy about is the new, somewhat pressured tipping system in which if you use your credit/debit card to pay, a monitor shows a series of tipping buttons that you have to choose from (and which everyone in line can see): $1, $2, $3 and then under that, a really obnoxiously big button that reads "NO TIP" which makes you feel like a cheapskate (which I'm not) if you're on a very strict budget for whatever reasons and just want to treat yourself to the occasional cup of take-out coffee.

Also, I wish they'd set up their outdoor tables and chairs even if the autumn weather starts getting chilly. Personally, I love the autumn chill and would prefer to sit outside.

EDIT: Since writing this review I was informed that Metropolis employees don't see whether you tip them anything or not while using the electronic payment method mentioned above. text:
Village Crossing is at the crossroads between Niles and Skokie, and simultaneously at the junction between convenient and nightmarish.

The store selection is varied, with standout gems like Gourmet Pita and Dear Frank's nestled in between big box stores starved for business. All of the smaller shops seem to be suffering this starvation more so than the big retailers who have corporate interests willing to foot the bill for what one can be sure are ever skyrocketing lease prices. A premium paid to be on the vaunted Touhy avenue to ultimately no benefit.

Several stores have been choked out already, quirky shops like U-Spy and Disc Replay, and even the UPS location that was here. Let behind are empty stores and fewer reasons to be anywhere near a Best Buy.

Defying all logic, there seems to perpetually be a furniture outlet on the verge of foreclosure in the back lot.

The lot is unnavigable at best, funneling traffic into nightmarish, grizzly, contorted lanes dotted with pointless stop signs and suicidal pedestrians.

Recent additions include a Tilted Kilt that no one wanted and Another Sub Shop. There's also a Tilly's for some reason. No one knows what happens in Tuesday Morning. And the Radio Shack disappeared before the bankrupt chain could even run a clearance sale.

An AMC happens to be hidden somewhere in this monstrosity, bouying and validating all of the attached stores through a somewhat parasitic relationship.

There's a decent Red Robin here, and a relatively nice Barnes and Noble. The Half Price Books is worth visiting but only barely.

text:
I would give 0 stars if it was possible! We had a horrible experience with Papa Saverio's tonight! We go here often... so we are very disappointed!! My husband got there to pick up our pizza and they said it got stuck in the oven and was all messed up. They showed it to him and it was a complete mess! They offered a small discount or to make a new one. He asked them to make a new one because it didn't even resemble a pizza and would have been hard to eat. So they did and said they would remake a small that was fine, but would be cold. But when he asked to remake the appetizers (including fried foods) they refused! He had to wait another 15 minutes for the pizzas to be done...and they were sitting out on the counter the whole time! Then they only offered an even  smaller discount for all of this! He walked out without anything! Unbelievable that this was the level of customer service that they offer. We won't be going back!

In response to the owner's reply... the only reason it was nearly $100 worth of food was because you had to remake it. If we had felt valued and you had offered or even accepted my husband's request to remake the appetizer,  we would have taken the food.  It had been sitting on the counter for over 30 minutes when you called to say the new pizzas were ready! That is ridiculous and we will not pay for food that is cold and been sitting out, not even in a warmer! Then you call at 8 pm...2 hours after we were to pick up the original pizzas... to ask us to come pick up the food and to pay for it! That is so rude and unacceptable! We have been places where something has been wrong with a meal or a pizza and they comp the item for the inconvenience and the extended wait!  I'm not saying you should have comped the whole thing,  but you could have offered more than a 15% discount with over an hour wait from when the order was placed and cold appetizers!  I have posted this here and on Facebook and I will continue to post it on other sites! You need a lesson on customer service!

Very nice theater.  Free parking and BOYB, what more could you ask for.    The lobby is comfy and homey and there is a bar with cookies and M&Ms.  The lobby feels intimate, like someone's home.  The theater itself is in an oblong room.  The seats are six across with big letters to denote the rows.  There are six seats in each row.  Rows are kind of close to each other...you can't walk pass folks in comfortably.

The performance we went to see was A Love Affair by Jerry Mayer.  It was an interesting play about a 38 year marriage, funny and serious, with two sets of actors playing the older and younger version of the couple.  The actors and actresses were very good, drawing me into the story.  Not sure if all of the performances are this good, but I would be willing to go back here to see another performance. text:
I had only eaten here once before a long time ago, but I drive by it all the time and I'd seen recently that they're in the process of revamping the place, so I wanted to give it another try.

We got the Chicken Tikka Pizza and the Chicken Fried Rice. The pizza was really good, the dough tasted like it was made from scratch. The Chicken Tikka was a nice twist, I don't think I've ever seen that before. My wife and I both really enjoyed it.

The Chicken Fried Rice wasn't bad by any means, I think they just need to tweak the recipe a bit. I think it was a little heavy on the pepper. I don't know if Pakistani fried rice is supposed to be different from Chinese/Japanese fried rice, but it didn't quite taste like the fried rice that I expected. But they did include soy sauce packets which made it better.

The owner was also super friendly, they had really good customer service.

Overall both my wife and I really enjoyed it and we'll probably add it to our rotation of restaurants for when we don't feel like cooking.
prediction_reason: The review discusses the location and shares a genuine experience, specifically mentioning aspects of the business or service. The star rating aligns with the tone of the review.

text: The in store food is pretty awful here.  The premium gasoline contains ethanol which is a big problem for modern Stihl carburetors.  The labeling is deceptive on the gas pumps and I had to ask an employee if the premium gasoline contained ethanol.  This shouldn't be such a confusing process and can lead to equipment damage or problems with long term storage for vehicles.  Also, the gas pumps have little televisions on them and instead of showing the news or the weather, they bombard you with right wing messages and religious themed broadcasts.  I don't necessarily have a problem with conservative ideology or religion in general, but if I want that kind of information, I will go to a church or watch a conservative news program.  I certainly don't like having to deal with this stuff while I am pumping my gas.  With regards to the food, Bud's tries to emulate the type of food one would find at a Casey's but they do it very poorly.  The hot dogs are disgusting (compared to other gas station hot dogs), the baked goods are either improperly stored or available for sale too long.  The muffins and donuts are almost always stale. Actually, I can say that they are always stale as I have never had a fresh muffin or donut from this place and I have been here pretty early in the morning.  The general cleanliness of the store terrifies me so I will never eat their chicken or pizza (which appears to be frozen pizza just heated up and put in a warmer).  I have seen employees touching their face or hair and then go right back to food preparation.  So, to summarize, premium gasoline costs premium prices, but does have ethanol in it, so gas bad.  Food that should have been thrown away or sold as 'day old' is in the displays as fresh.  Pumping gas can be irritating.  I don't mind news.  I don't mind conservative news, but I don't want to listen to idiot pundits shouting at each other about topical events while I am pumping my gas.  I love our country, but the 'patriotic' pump broadcasts are jingoistic and can be called nothing else except propaganda.  Also, while spending 50 bucks on gas, I don't want to listen to a evangelist wearing six pounds of gold jewelry asking me to donate to their church.  If you want a quick primer on the major failing points of our country go ahead and pump some gas here.  I cannot stress enough that I love my country, however, I love it enough to be disgusted by the broadcasts from the pumping station televisions.  I have been here multiple times when I needed 93 octane gasoline, probably about 30 before I learned that the premium gas here contains ethanol.  The baked goods were never fresh or even remotely good and I was constantly bombarded by religious and jingoistic propaganda.  It is horribly ironic that most of our current military involvement concerns oil in one way or another and this gas station bombards you with pro-war sentiments while you are pumping your gas.  Also, I have no problem with religion, but I do have a problem with evangelists that preach the only way to salvation is by giving them enough money so they can keep their swimming pools heated.  I have never been to a gas station in North Korea, but I have a feeling that with a few minor adjustments the programming on the pump televisions would work just as well there.  I have not been back since I found out that their premium gasoline contains ethanol.
prediction_reason: The review shares a genuine experience related to the business, with specific mention of the location being 'beautiful' which can plausibly describe the museum, and the 5-star rating aligns with the positive sentiment.

text:
CONCEPT: Love the combination of influences from Macau and Portugal (each dish says what region inspired the dish, or if it is a Fat Rice original). The diversity of flavors at this place is amazing...as my friend said you may think you know what you are getting when you order it but you will be surprised.

WAIT TIME: Came here last night with 2 friends and it was BUSY for a Tuesday night...even though we had a reservation, we still had to wait a few minutes, but nothing unreasonable.

AMBIANCE/SEATING: Not too big of a restaurant but most seating is at long wooden tables so you will be elbow to elbow with strangers. That said, it adds to the lively atmosphere...you get to check out what they are ordering (and maybe even let them influence your own ordering experience).

SERVICE: Both the hostess and the servers were friendly and professional. Our waitress was attentive but not overbearing, a perfect combination. Each time a dish was brought out (often by a different server), they describe the dish which just gets you excited to eat it!

FOOD: As I talked about in the CONCEPT section, the flavors here are so diverse and not stuff you will find anywhere else. The food is meant to share so we ordered a bunch of dishes. The menu did have "November  2018" at the top so it likely changes and you may not be able to find the below dishes in the future.

Fava Escabeche: Pickled fava beans which were a great pallate cleanser for the rest of the meal

Bacalhau de vovo: Salted cod spread over Portuguese bread...delicious! Reminded me of hummus.

Pork + Ginger Dumplings: Similar to dumplings you'll find elsewhere but with woodear mushrooms (yum!)

"Cereal" Spaghetti Squash: Spaghetti Squash in a coconut milk broth topped with corn flakes. This was so good this had me saying that I would eat corn flakes in coconut milk as a snack...and now I'm craving that.

Raba Raba: Perhaps my favorite dish...stir-fried mixed greens in an amazing sauce...I wish I could make greens like this at home.

Lacassa: Rice noodle stir fry which reminded me of really good street food I found in Southeast Asia. Add some of the Diablo sauce on top for an extra kick!

Kari Kapitan: Spicy Chili Chicken with Chinese Bacon. We ordered rice just to let it soak in this sauce.

VALUE: Definitely on the pricier side for the portion size but I am happy to pay for a great meal.

OVERALL: Loved my meal here and would definitely come back (I hear they have a good brunch too!)

text: We live in Florida, but visit twice a year and have been wanting to visit this place during our travels since my son was born 2 years ago, it just hasn't worked out until now and now I'm sorry it didn't earlier. This place lives up to it's rave reviews and now I know why first hand. We visited on a Wed. night and the place was hopping for their fish fry that didn't disappoint either. Upon arrival, my son unfortunately had constipation (not to be so blunt) but the reason I mention it is because our server was absolutely devoted to getting whatever my son needed to help his hurting tummy. She was so accommodating based on my unusual requests and delivered on every one of them and we had barely even sat down yet. We were seated in the back corner along the windows, but perfectly set in a quieter spot with 2 toddlers as to not create commotion with their ups and downs. We all ordered our beverages and food and she was very attentive and prompt. The food was absolutely delicious and the portions were amazing, my sister and I split two meals and we couldn't even finish one together. The fish fry might have been the best I've seen and they do it perfect from there being more fish than breading on each piece and the fish not being greasy inside, to the perfectly cooked fries and hush puppies, it was amazing. We also ordered the fish tacos which seemed to have the same fish and was everything we were hoping. My grandma ordered a Reuben that she said was very good and coming from a long history of being in the restaurant business, she was impressed. A gentleman stopped by, who seemed to be the manager or owner and was just extremely personable. He checked on how everything was going, including how my son was doing and then surprised both toddlers with their very own flight crew t-shirts. Of course they put them on immediately and thought they were so cool as they were describing everything they saw on the runway outside of the window. If you have kids, don't wait to go here, they will be in awe with all the things to see and the cool paper airplane like toy they give to the kids "upon departure." And while we didn't see any airplanes that night, we would head back in a heartbeat for the awesome atmosphere and staff, and delicious food! Thanks Pilot Pete's for making a precious family night one for the memory books.
prediction_reason: The review contains promotional keywords and a URL link, indicating the primary purpose is promotion, despite the high star rating.

Again 3 stars because of how the Tandoori Chicken was served. They had a limited variety of Indian dishes compared to other Indian buffet and restaurants I experienced . They tried to do their version of Chinese Vegetarian fried rice with Basmati rice but it was a "Meh" as well as their version of Chinese Sesame seed coated Chicken" LOL. text:
CONSUMER FRAUD WARNING!

Given the other reviews my experience might be a one off issue but it may point to a more serious problem.  Let me start off by saying the people we interacted with at the location were very friendly and the service was of good quality.

That being said, we received a mail advertisement for free teeth whitening from Park Place Dental Group with service for new patients.  That incentive, coupled with my wife losing her job at Vatterott and needing to use the benefits before the end of the year, lead us to seek service from Park Place Dental.  When receiving the annual cleaning, I was informed I needed a 4 quad descaling.  I made it very clear at the time that given the benefits were expiring and that this is non emergency service, the quote must be accurate; I was assured it was accurate.  We were quoted a payment of $555.00 out of pocket, which was paid in full, and insurance covered the remainder (50% plus some).  Services were rendered late ‚Äô18.

In April ‚Äô19, we received notification from Park Place Dental that the insurance provider (Aetna), did not cover the quoted expenses and we were to pay the additional unpaid balance of $565.  Upon further investigation with Aetna, they stated that they cover 50% of their listed supplier price of $108 per quad and Park Place Dental charged $265 per quad.

It was a cold slap in the face to find that I could have received the same service from another dentist and paid $123 less than what I had already paid with 0% insurance involvement; all for a ‚Äúfree‚Äù teeth whitening.  I was left in the position that Aetna stated that Park Place Dental, intentionally or unintentionally, misrepresented expenses and Park Place Dental stating Aetna misrepresented coverage to them.

I attempted to resolve this issue through Park Place Dental‚Äôs Office Manager Kelli.  However, in the end, Park Place Dental's position was to seek reimbursement from me for the additional $565 with the offer to set up a payment plan.  I made clear that if that was their position I would have to pursue this issue as consumer fraud and got 10 months of silence.

Recently, I have received another invoice for payment of the $565 so I am forced to pursue this issue as consumer fraud.  I have filed complaints with the Better Business Bureau, Illinois Attorney General and the American Dental Association.

I heavily caution any consumer considering doing business with Park Place Dental.
prediction_reason: The review is unrelated to the location, lacks direct reference to experiences at this business, and seems more like self-promotion or parochial commentary.

text:
I work at the Kitchn Chicago and share space with some of the most highly regarded and creative bakers and chefs in the city. Let's say I know the difference between a gourmet cupcake and Betty Crocker.

Driving on the main road, Two Girls and a Cupcake is visually the most attention grabbing structure, as it is bright pink.
Utica is adorable. It looks like someone copied and pasted a picture perfect small town from an 80s movie. It's manicured and picturesque. Everyone smiles and waves.

Went in Sunday with my girlfriend and got 12 assorted cupcakes. While we felt a tad rushed, we ended up taking our time and nobody was rude. It just felt like someone had a long day.

First off, this place is spotless. The prep area is visible from where you order and while we were there, a younger female was piping a light frosting onto chocolate cupcakes.

The variety of cupcakes was solid and the 6 or so I ate were all drastically different and all were very tasty.

You can tell a lot of effort went into creating the recipes and the cupcakes are all prepared meticulously. Almost every cupcake had a filling in the center. Every cupcake was different and garnished beautifully.

Here were the ones that I recall:
Cake Batter - Dead on, a little heavy on the almond flavor (fine by me). Appears to be a yellow chiffon with cake batter frosting and a reservoir of frosting in the middle. Killer cupcake. I love the detail with the cake crumbs. As soft and light as an angel food cake. Frosting is the correct density, not like heavy store bought frosting at all.

Cherry Cheesecake - Ditto. Dead on. Yellow batter, rich dark cherry flavor, a cherry on top and a cherry in the center of the cupcake. Unmistakable cheesecake flavor. Another dead on cupcake.

Chocolate Cream Pie - Do I have to write this? It tastes exactly like a chocolate cream pie. Probably the least striking visually; topped with chocolate chips and frosting, very rich chocolate batter, not too sweet, not dry. Right on the money.

Coconut Cream Pie - OK, I'm seriously not writing this. Like someone shrunk a coconut pie. Killer.

At $34 a dozen, it may seem expensive, but gourmet cupcakes in Chicago (I'm assuming most travelers to Utica are Chicagoans)are right around this price range and make no mistake- these are gourmet. They may be the best cupcakes I've ever had, I just dont want to piss off my colleagues.

As far as customer service goes... *shrug*
Everything was fine. Not everyone has to kiss every square inch of your ass to get you to buy their stuff. Go by the crepe stand at the farmers market in Chicago and ask the French guy something stupid. I'll bet you you've never received a tongue lashing like that over a pancake before.

As far as closing early goes, gourmet places reserve the right to do so. Places do it all the time, especially small town bbq joints, where it's "once we're out, we're out, see you tomorrow." Nobody complains because they know bbq takes time and is expensive to throw away. Gourmet baked goods are no different. Try to understand people- it isn't just eggs, sugar and flour otherwise EVERYONE would be able to make them. And NO, you can't just hang on to them if they don't sell. Baked goods take a big hit in quality in just 24 hours, so if you're obsessive about quality, selling yesterday's cupcakes today isn't an option. It's a good business model for maintaining product quality.

Bottom line- Great gourmet cupcakes in a quaint small town. Don't expect to get your ass kissed. Expect to drop $40.

Just a word of advice to ownership. While I may be a laid back and understanding customer, most people want an experience.
